In terms of its ecological and sustainable nature, electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) is widely recognized as the ideal solution to replace conventional ammonia production techniques. Unfortunately, poor Faraday efficiency (FE) with lower e-NRR selectivity limits its large-scale application. Previous studies have identified Mo2C as an optimistic electrocatalyst for e-NRR, exhibiting great ammonia yield. However, Mo2C suffers from Mo leaching during the electrochemical reaction process, thus reducing the stability of the catalyst. Herein, we propose a new electrocatalyst based on first-principles calculations: HB/α-Mo2C. This heterostructure is composed of Mo2C covered with a layer of Honeycomb Borophene (HB). The HB layer serves two purposes: to ensure the stability of the catalyst and improve the FE of the reaction. Our findings demonstrate the HB/α-Mo2C performs the highest catalytic activity via a mixed mechanism with a limiting potential as low as -0.16 V, which was determined to be caused by the transfer of electrons from the active sites of the boron atoms to the adsorbate. Furthermore, the limiting potential of HER, a competing reaction, was found to be as high as −0.56 V, confirming the high efficiency of HB/α-Mo2C towards e-NRR. This present work contributes to the development of new strategies for e-NRR catalyst design. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 2D materials Heterostructure Electrochemistry Nitrogen reduction reaction First-principles calculation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid industrialization and modernization of today's society caused a series of unexpected problems such as the over-depletion of fossil fuels and massive discharge of industrial wastes. This in turn led to major environmental and energy issues [1,2]. Consequently, it is a top priority for the scientific community to discover clean and sustainable energy sources. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in ammonia (NH3) as a significant hydrogen carrier, primarily due to its prevalence as an alternative fuel in shipping, a precursor for fertilizer in agriculture, and an ingredient in household chemicals [3]. Nevertheless, ammonia production is still a challenging process. In nature, nitrogen fixation and reduction in the atmosphere can produce ammonia gas, however, this process cannot be reproduced at a large-scale industrial basis [4]. The Haber-Bosch process (HBP), developed more than a century ago, continues to be the prevailing technology utilized for the production of ammonia on a large scale. Nonetheless, owing to the inherent inactivity of the NN bond, HBP must be conducted under harsh conditions (T: 350∼550 °C, P: 15∼25 MPa) on the Fe/Ru catalysts. Additionally, the H2 used in the process comes from methane, which further aggravates greenhouse gas emissions [5-8]. Hence, it is imperative to establish a method of nitrogen fixation that is both ecological and capable of long-term sustainability. Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) under moderate conditions is thought to be best alternative to HBP. In contrast to the traditional HBP, the hydrogen used in e-NRR is derived from water, limiting environmental pollution [9-12]. Furthermore, the energy utilization rate of e-NRR is about one-fifth higher than that of HBP from the thermodynamics perspective [5]. However, the sluggish kinetics of nitrogen adsorption and high activation barrier of NN bond dissociation lead to a substantial rise in overpotential and a decrease in NH3 yield [13,14]. Furthermore, the use of water as an electrolyte also induces the competitive reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), decreasing e-NRR selectivity [15,16]. Consequently, developing an electrocatalyst for e-NRR that can enhance the Faraday efficiency (FE) and mitigate the effects of competitive reactions presents a significant challenge. MXenes, such as Mo2C, are predicted to be suitable substrates for nitrogen adsorption and activation due to their large surface area and abundant delocalized electrons [17-19]. Interestingly, Sun et al. found that nitrogen fixation on α-Mo2C (200) surface, despite displaying a high FE of about 40.2 %, suffered from Mo leaching, resulting in catalyst degradation [20]. To prevent the issue, they covered the α-Mo2C surface with a layer of graphene, allowing nitrogen to be directly adsorbed onto the graphene. However, despite resolving the catalyst degradation issue, the FE on the new electrocatalyst decreased to 19.2 %. In the prospect of developing a better electrocatalyst for e-NRR, it is essential to conduct further investigations into materials that can provide surface coverage for α-Mo2C as a protective layer while also possessing the potential for nitrogen fixation. As a newcomer in the family of two-dimensional materials, borophene possesses some common properties such as high conductivity, anisotropy, and large carrier mobility [21-26]. Specifically, it exhibits metallic properties and is currently the lightest and thinnest metallic body reported [27]. Furthermore, borophene is a type of nanomaterials that combines strength, flexibility, and toughness in its mechanical properties, showing broad prospects for material applications [28]. In 2015, Mannix et al. synthesized borophene exhibiting a 2-Pmmn phase on Ag(111) surface under ultrahigh-vacuum (UHV), marking the first instance of such synthesis [29]. Subsequently, the existence of β [30], χ [31], and honeycomb [32] phase borophene has been confirmed by theoretical and experimental works. In particular, the honeycomb borophene (HB) has attracted much attention due to its superconductivity and ability to host Dirac fermions [33-35]. Nevertheless, because a boron atom has one less electron than carbon, HB cannot exist on its own as a stable structure like graphene; it needs to be stabilized by a large supply of electrons from the substrate [36,37]. Currently, HB can only be synthesized on single-crystal Al(111) substrate by MBE method [32]. Theoretical studies predict that Al(111) substrate transfers 0.7 e− to a single boron atom, which is larger than that of Ag(111) substrate [38]. Substrates that can stabilize borophene and exert its catalytic performance are currently very limited, which restricts the application of borophene in catalysis. Herein we propose a heterostructure of α-Mo2C(200) covered with HB (HB/α-Mo2C), with the aim of combining their advantages and stabilizing each other to achieve excellent catalytic performance. Our first-principles calculations showed that the FCC-HCP configuration of HB/α-Mo2C performs the highest nitrogen fixation activity, through a mixed pathway, performing a minimal limiting potential (U L) of −0.16 V. These results confirm our hypothesis regarding HB/α-Mo2C as a promising e-NRR catalyst. 2 Theoretical basis All the density functional theory (DFT) calculations in this work were implemented using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [39]. The exchange-correlation interactions were executed through the utilization of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method, which is derived from the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [40], while electron interactions were depicted using projector-augmented waves (PAW) [41]. A plane-wave cut-off energy was set of 450 eV. All structures were subjected to a force threshold of −0.01 eV on each atom. Additionally, the energy convergence tolerance was established at 10−5 eV. To characterize the van der Waals (vdW) interactions, the calculation employed the DFT-D3 approach developed by Grimme [42]. A vacuum space measuring 15 Å was introduced vertically in order to mitigate the interaction between two neighbouring repeating slabs. For structure relaxation and density of states, we utilized the Monkhorst-Pack k-point grids with meshes of 5 × 5 × 1 and 5 × 5 × 3, respectively, to sample the Brillouin zone [43]. The Bader charge population [44] was employed to examine the distribution and transfer of atomic charges, while the VASPKIT software [45] was utilized to calculate the values of zero-point energy and entropy. To assess the stability of the heterostructure, the binding energy (E b) was determined through the utilization of the subsequent equation: (1) E b = ( E HB / α − Mo 2 C − E HB − E α − Mo 2 C ) where the E HB/α-Mo2C, E B, and E α-Mo2C represent the electronic energy of the heterostructure, honeycomb borophene, and α-Mo2C, respectively. In order to estimate the energy barrier of the e-NRR, the Gibbs free energy for each hydrogenation step was determined using the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model developed by Nørskov et al. [46-48]: (2) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G pH where ΔE represents the electronic energy, is derived from the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. ΔE ZPE, T, and ΔS are the zero-point energy change, T = 298.15 K, and the entropy change, respectively. ΔG U represents the impact of the applied potential U on the system and could be expressed as ΔG U = eU, where e is the number of the transferred electrons. Hence, a correlation exists between the limiting potential value (U L) and ΔG max, the Gibbs free energy change of the potential-determination step (PDS), which can be expressed as U L = -ΔG max /e. Under the limiting potential, the whole reaction paths exhibit exothermic behaviour. ΔG pH = kB T × ln10 × pH where k B denotes the Boltzmann constant, and the pH = 0 was applied for the whole work. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structure, stability, and properties of HB/α-Mo2C heterostructure The two-dimensional HB/α-Mo2C heterostructure was modeled using 4 × 4 × 1 supercell of honeycomb borophene and 3 × 3 × 1 supercell of α-Mo2C (200). The optimized single cells are shown in Fig. S1. The lattice mismatch from the lattice constants was found to be 3 %, which is consistent with experimentally synthesized HB/Al(111) heterostructure. Due to the distinct symmetry characteristics of HB and α-Mo2C, there exist only a limited number of initial high-symmetry stacking arrangements of HB on the (200) surface of α-Mo2C, namely FCC-HCP, FCC-TOP, and TOP-HCP (Fig. 1 ). TOP represents the position located directly above the B atom, whereas HCP and FCC refer to the hollow positions that align with either the C or bottom Mo atom. Interestingly, the optimized structure of HB/α-Mo2C in the FCC-HCP and TOP-HCP configurations stays planar, whereas, in the TOP-FCC configuration, borophene becomes corrugated. To find the configuration that exhibits the utmost stability, we calculated the binding energy of borophene on the substrate in all three possible configurations (Fig. S2). Our results suggest that FCC-HCP configuration exhibits the highest energy favorability, with a low binding energy of −61.85 eV compared to TOP-HCP (−49.07 eV) and TOP-FCC (−44.72 eV) configurations. This indicates that the HB/α-Mo2C configuration of FCC-HCP is thermodynamically stable. In addition, the kinetic stability of the structure can be evaluated via AIMD simulation (Standard molecular dynamics and NVT ensemble). As plotted in Fig. 2 , the temperature and energy fluctuate near the equilibrium state. After simulating at 350 K for 10 ps, there is no significant change in the structure of HB/α-Mo2C, and it could maintain a stable configuration (Fig. S3), which demonstrates that HB/α-Mo2C is also dynamically stable. Thus, we predict that the FCC-HCP is the most plausible configuration of HB/α-Mo2C and all subsequent calculations are based on this structure. To obtain a deeper understanding of the electronic characteristics of HB/α-Mo2C, the Projected band structure (Fig. 3 a) and PDOS (Partial Density of State) (Fig. 3b) were calculated. The absence of band gap and the fact that the Fermi energy levels intersect with several bands suggest that HB/α-Mo2C possesses conducting properties that originate from the superconductivity of HB. Additionally, according to the PDOS, Mo being the heaviest atom in the entire structure indicates that it is the main electron supplier, as shown in Fig. 3b. Thus, the predicted conductivity of HB/α-Mo2C makes it a potential catalyst for e-NRR. 3.2 Adsorption and activation of N2 Now that we have shown that HB/α-Mo2C can be used as a potential e-NRR catalyst, we explored the feasibility of the reaction over the catalyst by investigating nitrogen adsorption, the first step of the e-NRR. This step holds an importance for the subsequent hydrogenation steps. Typically, the adsorption of nitrogen on the catalyst can occur in two configurations, namely end-on and side-on. The two optimized N2 adsorption configurations are depicted in Fig. 4 a,b. For the end-on configuration, the N2 molecule is vertically adsorbed on the catalyst, while for the side-on, the N2 molecule is horizontally adsorbed at both ends, each binding to a B atom. Our results show a significant NN bond length difference between the two configurations. In the end-on configuration, the NN bond length is approximately equivalent to that in free N2 (1.11 Å). In the side-on configuration, however, the NN bond is noticeably stretched to 1.21 Å. Furthermore, in the end-on configuration, the adsorption energy value is very close to zero (−0.09 eV), corresponding to the repulsive interaction between N2 and the catalyst. In contrast, in the side-on configuration, N2 is chemically adsorbed on the surface with a favorable adsorption energy of −1.21 eV. Those results indicate that N2 molecule is likely to adsorb and activate with the side-on configuration. The factors influencing the disparity in adsorption between the two types were further investigated. Boron atoms adopt sp2 hybridization state with empty p orbitals vertical to the surface. Due to the electron-donating properties of the Mo2C substrate, the p-orbitals of B become partially occupied. Therefore, both of them possess the ability to receive electrons from the N2 3σg orbitals and contribute electrons to the unoccupied N2 1πg orbitals. Hence, in the side-on configuration, borophene and N2 interact via the 'acceptor-donator' mechanism (Fig. 4c), and therefore the simultaneous interaction of B atoms with the two N atoms on both sides maximize the weakening of NN bond (Fig. 4d) [49-51]. In contrast, the activation of the NN bond is comparatively weaker since electron donation of B atom to only one N atom. Next, the charge density difference with Bader charge analysis for both configurations was calculated, as presented in Fig. 5 . In the side-on configuration, electron depletion could be noticed around the NN bond and electron accumulation can be observed around the B-N bond, suggesting that while the B atoms supply electrons to the N2 molecule, the latter feeds back electrons to the B atoms, consistent with the ‘acceptor-donator’ mechanism. Additionally, our Bader charge analysis shows that the two B atoms in the dual-boron active site donate 0.33 electrons to one end and 0.39 electrons to the other end of the NN adsorbate, more than those in the end-on configuration (0.32 e). This supports the existence of stronger interaction of the side-on configuration depicted in Fig. 4d. Finally, the ‘acceptor-donator’ mechanism between HB/α-Mo2C and N2 molecule in both configurations was confirmed by PDOS diagrams (Fig. 6 ). After N2 adsorption, the HB-N2 interaction leads to charge reallocation, resulting in a distinct splitting of the π2p* orbital of N2 molecule. The 2p orbitals of B and N atoms in the side-on configuration have greater overlap below the Fermi level than that in the end-on. This suggests that the B-N bond in the side-on configuration is stronger than that in the end-on. This further proves that N2 fixing on HB/α-Mo2C is more likely to proceed by side-on configuration. 3.3 e-NRR mechanism for side-on configuration e-NRR proceeds via four pathways: distal and alternating mechanisms via end-on configuration, and consecutive and enzymatic mechanisms via side-on configuration. Each mechanism comprises six hydrogenation steps (proton-electron coupling). Hence, to further estimate the feasibility of HB/α-Mo2C as an electrocatalyst for e-NRR, we investigated consecutive, enzymatic, and mixed pathways as depicted in Fig. 7 . Following the consecutive pathway depicted in (Fig. 8 a,b), the initial hydrogenation of adsorbed N2 to *NNH results in NN bond stretching from 1.20 Å to 1.28 Å (Fig. S4), with the Gibbs free energy decreases to −1.05 eV. The second step (*NNH → *NNH2) further elongated the NN bond length to 1.47 Å and the ΔG value slightly increased to 0.20 eV, indicating the PDS over the consecutive pathway. Finally, the third protonation (*NNH2 → *N+NH3) breaks the NN bond and release the first NH3 molecule. The remaining N atom is adsorbed on the surface on a bridge site, with bond lengths of 1.41 Å and 1.43 Å. The free energy of this step exhibits downward by −1.01 eV, resulting in heat release. The final steps are the three consecutive hydrogenations of the remaining N atom and the release of the second NH3 molecule, with the ΔG values of −1.26, −1.07, and 0.16 eV, respectively. According to Fig. 8c,d, double N atoms undergo alternative protonation and the order of NH3 release changes to the fifth and sixth steps in the enzymatic mechanism. Throughout the enzymatic pathway, the free energy of the third, fourth, and sixth hydrogenation steps are all uphill by 0.24, 0.06, and 0.16 eV, respectively. Therefore, the third hydrogenation step (*NHNH → *NHNH2) is the PDS for the whole enzymatic pathway with a limiting potential value (−0.24 V) is slightly higher than that of the consecutive pathway (−0.20 V). We also investigated the mixed pathway where the reaction follows the first three steps consecutive mechanism and then goes through enzymatic mechanism. Interestingly, only the free energy of the last hydrogenation step in the mixed pathway (Fig. 8e) is uphill, and the limiting potential exhibits a notably low value of −0.16 V, lower than the values of most electrocatalysts. The limiting potential of all three pathways is below standard, −0.98 V (Ru(0001)). Bader charge analysis was performed for each step of the mixed pathway to better understand the high electrocatalytic performance of HB/α-Mo2C. Based on previous theoretical studies [52], HB/α-Mo2C can be divided into three moieties (Fig. 9 a): all HB/α-Mo2C excluding the active B atoms (moiety 1), the two B atoms interacting with NxHy (moiety 2), and adsorbate NxHy (moiety 3). The diagram of Fig. 8b illustrates the fluctuation in charge of three moieties within the mixed pathway. Our results show that the charge variation of moiety 1 slightly fluctuates. In comparison, the charge variation of moiety 2 and moiety 3 exhibits a mirrored fluctuation pattern, with a higher range of fluctuation. This demonstrates that the B atoms at the active sites are essential for the nitrogen molecule to dissociate, which lowers the energy barrier for the following protonation processes. 3.4 e-NRR selectivity In addition to catalytic activity, the HER reactivity is also a significant criterion for assessing the efficiency of electrocatalysts [53]. Therefore, we investigated the ability of catalysts to adsorb hydrogen. The optimized structure of H atom adsorbed on the catalyst is depicted in Fig. S5, with the adsorption free energy is −0.56 eV (Fig. 10 ), far from the ideal over potential of HER (0 V). The difference between e-NRR and HER limiting potentials can also serve as a means to assess the selectivity of e-NRR. A greater difference indicates a higher selectivity. Given the significant difference in the limiting potential between the mixed pathway (−0.16 V) and HER (−0.56 V), one can assume that HB/α-Mo2C has excellent e-NRR selectivity. 4 Conclusion In summary, we simulated HB/α-Mo2C heterostructure using DFT theory. The heterostructure is characterized by the rich delocalized electrons of Mo2C substrate and the high conductivity of HB. Furthermore, the strong binding of HB over Mo2C (Eb=−61.85 eV) and AIMD simulation results demonstrate the high stability of the HB/α-Mo2C heterostructure. Our results also suggest that nitrogen fixation occurs through a side-on adsorption configuration and follows a mixed mechanism, with the UL only −0.16 V, demonstrating the possible excellent electrocatalytic performance of HB/α-Mo2C. The NRR selectivity was confirmed due to the higher competition compared with HER. The limiting potential of HER was found to be much greater than that of all three pathways of NRR, demonstrating HB/α-Mo2C high selectivity towards NRR. If synthesized, the HB/α-Mo2C heterostructure may solve the problem of Mo leaching seen in HB/Al(111), and also improve the FE and e-NRR selectivity, which supports our original theory. Our study offers a promising approach to developing highly effective e-NRR catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In terms of its ecological and sustainable nature, electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) is widely recognized as the ideal solution to replace conventional ammonia production techniques. Unfortunately, poor Faraday efficiency (FE) with lower e-NRR selectivity limits its large-scale application. Previous studies have identified Mo2C as an optimistic electrocatalyst for e-NRR, exhibiting great ammonia yield. However, Mo2C suffers from Mo leaching during the electrochemical reaction process, thus reducing the stability of the catalyst. Herein, we propose a new electrocatalyst based on first-principles calculations: HB/α-Mo2C. This heterostructure is composed of Mo2C covered with a layer of Honeycomb Borophene (HB). The HB layer serves two purposes: to ensure the stability of the catalyst and improve the FE of the reaction. Our findings demonstrate the HB/α-Mo2C performs the highest catalytic activity via a mixed mechanism with a limiting potential as low as -0.16 V, which was determined to be caused by the transfer of electrons from the active sites of the boron atoms to the adsorbate. Furthermore, the limiting potential of HER, a competing reaction, was found to be as high as −0.56 V, confirming the high efficiency of HB/α-Mo2C towards e-NRR. This present work contributes to the development of new strategies for e-NRR catalyst design.
